subject: Re: [junit] todo tests in JUnit (think Perl)
msgSnippet: Hmm.  It seems that the functionality that you seek could be provided by handling test return codes other than fail (or the absence of fail ).  In previous
messageBody:
Hmm. It seems that the functionality that you seek could be provided by
handling test return codes other than "fail" (or the absence of "fail"). In
previous test harnesses, I have found it useful to bucket test statii as
follows:

PASS
FAIL
UNIMPLEMENTED
EXCEPTION
ABORT
UNKNOWN

Pass and fail to the obvious thing, and are the usual test status. Tests
that are defined but their class implementation isn't complete, or for
whatever reason the test hadn't been implemented can flag themselves as
Unimplemented. Unexpected exceptions that can be handled by the test would
flag an Exception status (this may seem redundant with Fail, except that the
test can handle the exception and continue). Abort means that the test
couldn't be setup (or torn down), or had some environmental problem.
Unknown is for good measure and is defined as "none of the above".

In the past, I have implemented these codes as static ints. In the JUnit
implementation, Fail is denoted by an AssertionFailedError, and silence is
golden.

Perhaps it would be simpler to implement these statii as additional methods
in framework.Assert class and add corresponding vectors and methods to
framework.TestResult? Something like Assert.assertUnimplemented() and
assertUnimplemented(String). It shouldn't be too hard to teach
framework.TestResult to tally the buckets and amend the test summary report.

Cheers,

_chas_

> jcarpenter@....

> We are finding that there are times when it may be desirable to check
> into source control code that is not fully implemented. The tests
> may be defined, but the corresponding class implementation may not be
> complete.
>
> Perl's standard framework has the concept of a todo test. A simple
> enough way to notate such a test in JUnit would be to name a method
> within a test todoBlah, rather than testBlah. To safely go down this
> road, it is desirable to extend JUnit to report on what todo tests
> are in the code base in addition to the normal tests. I am
> considering writting such an extension and contributing it back to
> the JUnit project. Unfortuantely, I don't know where in the JUnit
> code base to start.
>
> Can you provide guidance as to what classes would need to be changed
> to support this functionality? Do you have any suggestions
> to improve the idea? Ideally this can fit into JUnit's normal
> extension framework.
>
> Thank you for your time and consideration.
>
> Jimmy Carpenter
> jcarpenter@...

> Erik Meade kindly responded with the following:

> Jimmy,
>
> I think the class you want to start with is junit.framework.TestSuite.
> Take a look at the constructor which accepts a Class. I believe this
> is where the tests get loaded by reflection...
>
> If you want more input I would suggest you post this to the JUnit
